quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: Most people when they try to calm down, they use tactical reframes or maybe mindfulness. But working with the physiology, using what's known as a bottom up approach, primarily using the breath, it's just such a rapidly more effective way of shifting your state.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: There's four times more afferent neurons going from the body to the brain as from the brain to the body. So by learning how to pull on the levers of our physiology, we can rapidly change our state. And then from there, by changing our state, that impacts the thoughts and feelings that we have.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: I call it, if this, then breathe. So it's like if I feel overwhelmed, then I do the humming. If I feel anxious, then I do 4, 4, 8 breathing or alternate nostril breathing and kind of having my own little recipe set that I have for different context is really helpful.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: Interoception is known as our sixth sense, and basically it's our ability to sense, track and feel our internal landscape. In the same way that you train your flavor palette for sweet, spicy, umami, you can also train your interoceptive palette and become more aware of the internal sensations.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: I have this idea that I call the feather brick dump truck phenomenon. When we are showing early signs of burnout, our body will give us feedback usually in subtle ways in the beginning. Ideally, you want to notice when it's the feather and then make adjustments, not have to wait until you experience the full-blown pain of the dump truck.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: When our nervous system experiences stress, if that cycle isn't completed or we don't get to downshift or relax on the other side, that gets stored in the body as allostatic load, which I call emotional debt. And over time, that creates fragility in the nervous system.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: One really key sign is if you are not able to naturally downshift or down regulate your nervous system at the end of the day without something like wine or CBD or some kind of external substance, that's a sign that you kind of reached a certain threshold of emotional debt.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: I'm not a big fan of talk therapy alone or at least therapy that doesn't have a somatic or body-based component. Just talking about things and keeping things on the level of the intellect doesn't actually address the root of the challenge. What we need to do is create a certain sense of safety to go into those buffered emotional responses and feel them all the way through.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: If someone has a thought of like, oh no, I'm nervous before this important presentation, that exacerbates the breathing pattern and then the whole thing just goes into this spiral. No great decisions were made from that place of reactivity. So being able to downshift your system, access a sense of safety, and then moving on from there is a profoundly practical skill.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: If they are avoiding feeling a certain way, let's say that they don't enjoy feeling conflict or anger, then they will make decisions subconsciously to avoid feeling that way. And it becomes a huge bias. If you are able to welcome and be with whatever emotions would arise on the other side of a decision, you're able to decide clearly instead of being skewed one way or the other.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: The nervous system of an organization is a reflection of the nervous system of the CEO. The leader or the CEO has a disproportionate impact, their emotional state has a disproportionate impact on the people in their team.

quotes.speaker: Jonny Miller
quotes.text: Building emotional debt is very much like building technical debt in the early days of a startup. It's worth doing, but just do it intentionally. Know that you're doing that. So let's say you work really hard for eight months, you give yourself a month or two off to really downshift.

takeaways: State over story: instead of trying to talk yourself out of anxiety, change your physiology first through breathwork - your mind will follow your body's lead.
Build an 'if this, then breathe' toolkit - a personalized recipe of specific breathing exercises for different emotional states like overwhelm, anxiety, or low energy.
Emotional debt accumulates like technical debt: your body stores incomplete stress cycles, and if you don't intentionally pay it off, it compounds into burnout and health crises.
If you need wine or CBD to unwind at the end of the day, that is a clear signal your emotional debt has reached a critical threshold requiring intervention.
The nervous system of an organization mirrors the nervous system of its CEO - your unprocessed stress and reactivity cascades through the entire team.

contrarian_candidates.why: Challenges the dominance of talk therapy by arguing that intellectual processing alone cannot address the root of emotional challenges - the body must be involved
Argues that the best decision-making is emotional, not rational - directly counters the Silicon Valley bias toward data-driven, feelings-free decision-making
Reframes burnout as an intentional trade-off akin to technical debt rather than something to simply avoid - you can choose to build it if you plan to pay it off
